Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: GOUVERNANCE, SÉCURITÉ ET ÉTAT DE DROIT
Outcome: Des institutions légitimes et redevables garantissent l’État de droit, la bonne gouvernance et le respect des droits humains
Output: Produit 1.1. La représentation et la participation des différentes parties prenantes au processus inclusif de révision/reforme de la constitution est améliorée pour accompagner le processus de renforcement institutionnel
Sub-Output: Augmentation du taux de détection de marchandises illicites provenant de conteneurs examinés, sur la base du profilage et de l'évaluation des risques.
Description:
Le projet, suite à la demande du ministre haïtien de l'Économie et des Finances en juillet 2023, vise à renforcer les capacités nationales en matière de gestion des frontières pour lutter contre le trafic illicite, le crime organisé et le terrorisme, tout en augmentant la collecte des recettes. Le résultat principal attendu est la création d'unités de contrôle (PCU) au sein du programme de contrôle des conteneurs (CCP) et du projet de communication aéroportuaire (AIRCOP). Ces unités, composées de douaniers, de policiers et d'autres agents des forces de l'ordre, auront pour mission de cibler, contrôler et inspecter les conteneurs et le fret à haut risque. 

Les bénéficiaires de ce projet incluent les forces de l'ordre, les agences gouvernementales, ainsi que les communautés locales directement touchées par les activités criminelles. Le projet a une durée totale de deux ans, débutant en juillet 2023 et se terminant en juillet 2025, avec un budget global fourni par le ministre des Finances d'Haïti, complété par des fonds de l'Union européenne, de l'Allemagne et un accord de financement avec le gouvernement du Canada pour établir les unités de contrôle à Ouanaminthe, Belladère, Malpasse et Anse-à-Pitre. L'ONUDC prévoit également d'étendre ce programme pour développer un projet transfrontalier en collaboration avec la République dominicaine afin de renforcer les contrôles aux frontières.
Agencies: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
Contributing partners: Embassy of Germany, European Union, Global Affairs Canada, The US Government Department of State's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Implementation partners: Programa de las Naciones Unidas para el Desarrollo, United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
SDG Targets: 1.1 By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.,8.1 Sustain per capita economic growth in accordance with national circumstances and, in particular, at least 7 per cent gross domestic product growth per annum in the least developed countries.,10.1 By 2030, progressively achieve and sustain income growth of the bottom 40 per cent of the population at a rate higher than the national average.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth, 10 Reduced Inequalities
Geography: Ouest, Ganthier, Belladère, Ouanaminthe, Anse-à-Pître, Port-au-Prince, Nord-Est, Centre, Sud-Est, Haiti
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 3 - Sustaining Peace is the principal objective
2024 Narrative: Suite à une demande du ministre haïtien de l'économie et des finances en juillet 2023, une proposition de coopération stratégique entre l'Office des Nations Unies contre la drogue et le crime (ONUDC) et l'administration générale des douanes du gouvernement haïtien a été approuvée avec pour objectif général de renforcer les capacités nationales en matière de gestion des frontières pour lutter contre le trafic illicite, le crime organisé et le terrorisme, et d'augmenter la collecte des recettes. Plus spécifiquement, l'effort se concentre surCartographier les réseaux criminels transnationaux ayant un impact sur Haïti ;Contrôler les conteneurs et faciliter leur mouvement au port international de Port-au-Prince, au port international de Cap-Haïtien, à Port Lafito, et aux frontières terrestres de Ouanaminthe, Belladère, Malpasse et Anse-à-Pitre avec la République dominicaine ; Plus précisément, ce programme vise à créer des unités de contrôle (PCU) établies dans le cadre de la mise en œuvre du programme de contrôle des conteneurs (CCP) et du projet de communication aéroportuaire (AIRCOP). Ces unités de contrôle sont des unités multi-agences composées de douaniers, de policiers et d'autres agents des forces de l'ordre en fonction des menaces qui pèsent sur le pays. L'objectif de ces unités est de cibler, de contrôler et d'inspecter les conteneurs et le fret à haut risque. Les agents de l'UCP sont formés à la gestion des risques, au profilage et à l'analyse afin de minimiser le risque que les conteneurs maritimes et le fret aérien soient exploités pour le trafic et d'autres formes d'activités criminelles organisées. Ils seront donc composés de personnel de l'Administration Générale des Douanes (AGD), du Bureau de Lutte contre le Trafic de Stupéfiants (BLTS), de Polifront et/ou de la Garde Côtière Haïtienne.  Les fonds de démarrage du programme ont été fournis par le ministre des Finances d'Haïti et complétés par des fonds de l'UE et de l'Allemagne par l'intermédiaire du Fonds commun de la police. En outre, l'ONUDC a conclu un accord de financement avec le gouvernement du Canada pour établir les unités de contrôle à Ounaminthe, Belladere, Malpasse et Anse-a-Pitres.  L'ONUDC prévoit maintenant d'étendre ce programme pour développer un projet transfrontalier dans lequel la République dominicaine et Haïti travailleraient ensemble pour renforcer les contrôles transfrontaliers.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Peace, Safety, Justice, and the Rule of Law
Outcome: Regional and national laws, policies, systems, and institutions improve access to justice and promote peace, social cohesion, and security
Output: MSDCF 7.2: Governance mechanisms strengthened to protect and advance human rights, combat corruption, reduce crime and curb violence
Sub-Output: TTO Roadmap for Implementing The Caribbean Priority Actions on the Illicit Proliferation of Firearms and Ammunition across the Caribbean in a Sustainable Manner by 2030
Description:
1.	Development of National Action Plan within the framework of the Caribbean Firearms Roadmap and support provided for Reporting via Monitoring and Evaluation Webinars and Workshops on Data Collection, Analysis and Reporting
2.	Strengthening institutional capacity via training courses for law enforcement officials, specifically, (i) Combating Arms and Ammunition Trafficking (CTAM) Course and (ii) National Specialized Interdicting Small Arms, Ammunition, Parts and Components (ISAAPC)
3.	Donation of a Comparison Microscope to support the examination of ballistic evidence at the Trinidad and Tobago Forensic Science Centre in an effort to address firearm related crimes
Agencies: United Nations Regional Centre for Peace, Disarmament and Development in Latin America and the Caribbean
Contributing partners: Government of Canada, The US Government Department of State's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Implementation partners: Caribbean Community Implementation Agency for Crime and Security (CARICOM IMPACS), Trinidad and Tobago Ministry of National Security
SDG Targets: 16.4 By 2030, significantly reduce illicit financial and arms flows, strengthen the recovery and return of stolen assets and combat all forms of organized crime.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2024 Narrative: (1)	Monitoring and Evaluation Reporting Series: UNLIREC and CARICOM IMPACS, as co-custodians of the Caribbean Firearms Roadmap (CFRM), collaborated to deliver a regional capacity building series on monitoring and evaluation for the CFRM. This strengthened government capacity for reporting as well as the development of National Action Plans towards combatting firearms trafficking in line with the CFRM goals and Sustainable Development Goal 16, “Peace, justice, and strong institutions” (Target 16.4).(2)	Combatting Arms and Ammunition Trafficking Course: UNLIREC enhanced the skills and capacity of thirty-three officials from law enforcement as well as legal and scientific institutions to combat arms and ammunition trafficking in Trinidad and Tobago. Officials with responsibilities for arms and ammunition control, received contemporary training to, inter alia, prevent and combat trafficking, illicit manufacturing and illicit brokering. Key personnel are now equipped with new knowledge and technical tools to implement strategies to prevent and combat trafficking in firearms and ammunition in line with international instruments. (3)	Comparison Microscope Donation to the Trinidad and Tobago Forensic Science Centre:The Trinidad and Tobago Forensic Science Centre now has greater capacity to examine firearms and ammunition at its laboratory, following the provision of a Firearms and Tools Marks Comparison Microscope and related training. Twenty-three scientific officers are now better equipped to examine fired ammunition evidence (i.e. bullet and cartridge cases) from shooting incidents including homicide and wounding cases. This builds upon the centre´s continuous support to the laboratory, which was initiated in 2016 and included support in, inter alia, firearm examination, evidence storage management and case management.

2022 Narrative: IOM developed and delivered model counter-smuggling legislation to CARICOM IMPACS. In the process of developing this model legislation, IOM and CARICOM IMPACS collaborated to convene a consultation and meeting entitled ‘Legislative and practical pathways towards the enforcement of counter-smuggling of migrants in the CARICOM region’, which was held in Trinidad and Tobago on the 26th and 27th of April, 2022.
2023 Narrative: In consultation with CARICOM Member States, including Barbados and the OECS, IOM for CARICOM IMPACS, developed Standard Operating Procedures for frontline officers on countering migrant smuggling, complementary to the Model Legislation on the Prevention and Countering of Smuggling of Migrants.
2024 Narrative: CARICOM IMPACS, IOM and UNODC met in Barbados from 29-30 October to develop a coordinated action plan, mapping activities and resources to combat the serious crimes of the smuggling of migrants and trafficking in persons. The meeting, which included a capacity-building session, resulted in an Action Plan with concrete collaborative actions to be implemented in the the next three years.

Sub-Output: UNODC XBSZ64 CdE National authorities' capacities strengthened to produce studies and analyses on drug policies and trends through the Center of Excellence on Illicit Drug Supply Reduction (UNDP)
Description:
Project: Center of Excellence on Illicit Drug Supply Reduction
Actual start date: 25/05/2020 | End date: 31/12/2023

The Center of Excellence (CoE) aims to produce evidence-based information on the supply of illicit drugs in Brazil. CoE provided scientific evidence on trends and threats posed by drug trafficking and transnational organized crime and disseminated this information to the government, civil society and the press. 

The project is the result of a partnership between the National Secretariat for Drug Policy and Asset Management of the Ministry of Justice and Public Security (SENAD/MJSP), the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP).
Agencies: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
Contributing partners: Brazilian Ministry of Justice and Public Security
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Justice and Public Security
SDG Targets: 16.4 By 2030, significantly reduce illicit financial and arms flows, strengthen the recovery and return of stolen assets and combat all forms of organized crime.,16.a Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Data Collection and Analysis, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: The Center of Excellence for Illicit Drug Supply Reduction (CoE) aims to produce evidence-based scientific information on the supply of illicit drugs in Brazil and on trends and threats posed by drug trafficking and transnational organized crime. It is a partnership between UNODC, UNDP, and the National Secretariat for Drugs and Asset Management of the Ministry of Justice and Public Security (SENAD/MJSP) of Brazil.During the year, UNODC and SENAD reformulated the Center of Excellence for Illicit Drug Supply Reduction into the Center for Studies on Drugs and Socio-Community Development (CDESC). The center’s scope of action was expanded to include demand reduction and innovative action (e.g., alternative development), to support evidence-based public policy. While maintaining the role of a center of research on illicit drugs, it will focus on innovation, care, treatment, prevention, human rights, alternative development, inclusion, and community-based interventions.In 2023, CoE/CDESC produced a series of publications, namely:The chapter on Amazon of the UNODC’s World Drug Report 2023.The Fourth Report of the Brazilian Early Warning Subsystem on Drugs in Brazil – “Fentanyl: characterization and presence in Brazil.”The Fifth Report of the Brazilian Early Warning Subsystem on Drugs in Brazil – “Synthetic cannabinoids: data on supply, demand and challenges in Brazil.”The study “Dynamics of the illicit drug market in Brazil (Vol. 2): Degree of purity of cocaine in four states.”, andThe publication “Drug trafficking in the Amazon region: initial findings.”The chapter on Amazon of the UNODC World Drug Report (WDR 2023) was important to bring forth the theme of the nexus between drugs and crimes that affect the environment and convergent crimes in the region, especially narco-deforestation and “narcogarimpo”, or narco-mining. The WDR brief on the Amazon was featured by Brazilian media, including “Jornal Nacional” and “Estadão”.The publication “Drug trafficking in the Amazon region: initial findings” focuses on the Brazilian Amazon and, beyond providing initial information on the subject, tries to identify future research possibilities. It was an important instrument to later inform the creation of an alternative development agenda in the region.Finally, the reports of the Brazilian Early Warning Subsystem on Drugs were important to map the rise of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS) in Brazil and its consequences on drug policy. They bring to attention the need to monitor the increase of NPS in Brazil while taking preventive measures to avoid reaching the tipping point of an epidemic.

Sub-Output: UNODC GLOX99 GMCP Law enforcement agencies' capacities strengthened to address transnational organized crime and illicit trafficking through fluvial means in the Amazon basin and in the tri-border area between Brazil, Paraguay, and Argentina
Description:
#SSC Colombia, Paraguay, Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, Mozambique, Nigeria, Senegal, South Africa and Tanzania.
Project: Global Maritime Crime Programme (GMCP).
Actual start date: 19/08/2022 | End date: End date: 30/09/2024.

GMCP assists Member States in enhancing and coordinating their efforts against maritime crime. In Brazil, GMCP has three fronts of action. The first aims to strengthen Brazil’s interagency capacity on river and maritime control and the country's prosecutorial capacity to disrupt organized crime in the Amazon basin, including cross-border cooperation with Northern neighbouring countries. The second focuses on the Southern Tri-Border of Brazil (with Paraguay and Argentina), aiming to equip law enforcement agencies and criminal justice sectors with skills to detect, interdict, investigate and prosecute threats in rivers, especially trafficking. Thirdly, GMCP promotes cooperation between Brazil and West African countries. GMCP is implemented under UNODC's mandate of the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and the Three International Drug Control Conventions.
Agencies: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
Contributing partners: Government of Canada, Government of Norway, The US Government Department of State - Bureau of Counterterrorism, The US Government Department of State's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs, United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: The US Government Department of State - Bureau of Counterterrorism, The US Government Department of State's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
SDG Targets: 16.4 By 2030, significantly reduce illicit financial and arms flows, strengthen the recovery and return of stolen assets and combat all forms of organized crime.,16.a Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.,17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
SDG Goals: 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women’s empowerment
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: GMCP assists Member States in enhancing and coordinating their efforts against maritime and riverine crime. In Brazil, GMCP has three fronts of action. The first aims to strengthen Brazil’s interagency capacity on river and maritime control and the country's prosecutorial capacity to disrupt organized crime in the Amazon basin, including cross-border cooperation with Northern neighbouring countries. The second focuses on the Southern Tri-Border of Brazil (with Paraguay and Argentina), aiming to equip law enforcement agencies and criminal justice sectors with skills to detect, interdict, investigate and prosecute threats in rivers, especially trafficking. Thirdly, GMCP promotes cooperation between Brazil and West African countries.In 2023, GMCP held several capacity-building activities. At the beginning of the year, UNODC organized the International Exchange on Operations in the riverine domain, at the Center for Integration and Improvement in Environmental Policing (CIAPA), in Brazil, between Brazil, South Africa, Mozambique, and Tanzania.Regarding the cooperation between Brazil and Paraguay, GMCP held a Bilateral Tactical Training on Riverine Operations and an International Exchange on Tactical and Operational Approaches to Crime in the riverine domain. Both activities aimed to improve the coordination between Brazilian and Paraguayan efforts against riverine crime in the Tri-Border region.The project made significant efforts to promote South-South cooperation between Brazil and West African countries, namely Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, Nigeria, and Senegal. In November, it organized the Inter-institutional Dialogues to foster the exchange of information between intelligence agents from Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, Nigeria, Senegal, and Brazil. In the same month, GMCP held the first phase of the Diving Course for ship hull sweeping. The course aims to train public security agents in basic and advanced diving to enable them to take part in the second phase of the training, which will enable them to carry out public security dives and conduct ship hull scans. The training was organized in partnership with the Brazilian Federal Police and was attended by nationals from Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, Nigeria, and Senegal.
2024 Narrative: Under UNODC’s mandate to prevent drug trafficking and organized crime, in 2024, UNODC trained 26 people in Public Security Diving and Ship Hull Inspection to increase the national capacity for detecting illicit cargo as criminal organizations increase the practice of hiding illicit drugs in ship hulls (https://tinyurl.com/bdctjcmr, https://tinyurl.com/2mveawmk). In tandem, GMCP donated public safety diving equipment to the Brazilian Federal Police, to accelerate port inspection of ships headed to export.  Firstly, UNODC offered basic and advanced diving lessons to Brazilian federal police officers and officers from selected West African countries: Senegal, Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, and Nigeria, as this is necessary to undergo the specific course on ship hull inspection. Then, this year, the first cohort (06 people) underwent the hull inspection course. The second and third cohorts started the diving training in 2024 and are expected to learn hull inspection in 2025. In 2024, Brazilian divers intercepted half a ton of cocaine in ship hulls at the Santos Port. Investing in South-South Cooperation, UNODC held tripartite meetings to address illicit flows, contraband, and transnational organized crime via river routes: two sessions between Brazil, Paraguay, and Colombia regarding the Paraná-Paraguay Rivers, and two sessions among Brazil, Colombia, and Peru on the Amazon River Basin. In addition, UNODC held two training sessions under the River Operations Exchange Program for public security agents from Brazil, Colombia, Peru, and Mozambique in conducting river and riverine operations in the Amazon region, held at the Center for Integration and Improvement in Environmental Police. As a result of the Paraná-Paraguay Rivers talks, UNODC will invest in operational training for river operations to address drug trafficking and illicit flows. In the northern area, the focus was on the exchange of best practices, the practical application of international policies, and the technical review of cooperation memoranda between the countries. Additionally, UNODC held a workshop on multivariate analysis methodologies in Quantum Geographic Information System (QGIS), to promote the use of spatial analysis tools to support law enforcement interventions in the fight against organized crime in the triple border region between Brazil, Colombia, and Peru.

Strategic priority: Peace: A peaceful, fair, and inclusive society
Outcome: Outcome 6: A peaceful, fair and inclusive society promoted through social participation, transparency and democratic governance, respecting the secularity of the State and ensuring human rights for all
Output: 6.2 Evidences produced and communication and advocacy strategies implemented and capable of supporting planning and transparent decision-making, combating violence and crime and, promoting human rights and access to justice, with due consideration to gender, race, ethnicity, origin, nationality and age
Sub-Output: UNODC UNDP Pilot Project of the Centre of Excellence for Illicit Drug Supply Reduction (CoE)
Description: The pilot project of the Centre of Excellence for Illicit Drug Supply Reduction (CoE Brazil) is the result of an innovative partnership between the National Secretariat for Drug Policy and Asset Management of the Ministry of Justice and Public Security (SENAD/MJSP), the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). The objective of the CoE is to contribute with qualified information on the supply of illicit drugs in Brazil by sharing evidence on illicit markets. Based on extensive research and analysis work, the CoE will provide scientific evidence to assist the Ministry in the preparation of studies on trends and threats posed by drug trafficking and transnational organized crime, as well as disseminate this information to government, civil society and the press.
Agencies: United Nations Development Programme, United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
Contributing partners: Brazilian Ministry of Justice and Public Security
SDG Targets: 16.a Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis, Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Other (including coordination), Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Support Functions
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2021 Narrative:
UNODC established, in partnership with UNDP and the National Secretariat on Drug Policy (SENAD) of the Ministry of Justice and Public Security (MJPS), the Centre of Excellence for Drug Supply Reduction (CoE) to elaborate studies on trends and threats on the topic of drug supply and to promote cooperation with neighbouring countries. During the year 2021 the Center of Excellence for Illicit Drug Supply Reduction (CoE) developed a series of activities. 
The project hosted the side event “Innovations in Brazilian Drug Policy” during the 64th session of the Commission on Narcotic Drugs (CND), which took place between 12 and 19 April 2021. CoE Brazil also organized a webinar to launch its first thematic bulletin: “Management of Assets from Drug Trafficking - Decapitalizing organized crime to strengthen public policies in Brazil” (https://drive.google.com/file/d/1merOwbE710ut1iExyqJGEDiyVNSQX3h8/view). By the end of the year, CoE hosted on 7-8 December the “International Seminar on Illicit Drug Supply Reduction: The Effects of COVID-19 Pandemic on Drug Trafficking”, in which the project launched its first strategic study: "COVID-19 and drug trafficking in Brazil: the adaptation of organized crime and the actions of police forces during the pandemic” (https://drive.google.com/file/d/1CsFHawV6CLCFlGDcUhXVHnE2QcTctfal/view). 
The study provides a broad perspective on the difficulties faced during the pandemic, as well as on the new dynamics of criminal groups that operate in transnational drug trafficking. It seeks to collaborate with the existing field of knowledge on the subject from the analysis of the Brazilian reality with the primary objective of subsidizing and supporting the continuous improvement of institutions that work to fight illicit drug trafficking and public policies in the area.
2022 Narrative: Aimed at national institutions involved in the response to drug trafficking and organized crime, the project is needed to provided reliable evidence on drug trafficking, its patterns and related themes. The project is furnishing extensive knowledge for the action of national institutions, particularly the Ministry of Justice and Public Security, while also supporting innovative initiatives to respond to this issue. In 2022, evidence to respond to drug trafficking was furnished through the publication, jointly with UNDP and the National Secretariat for Drug Policies and Asset Management (SENAD), of the Strategic Study Dynamics of the illicit drug market in Brazil: Comparative analysis of the prices of marijuana, cocaine and other drugs in four states. The Center also elaborated and published the Third Early Warning Subsystem on Drugs Report, the thematic bulletin Diagnosis of the Forensic Chemistry and Toxicology Laboratories of the Scientific Police of Brazil, the thematic bulletin Illicit Drug Price Monitoring: Lessons learned in Colombia and possible challenges in Brazil, and a report on benchmarking and good international practices for illicit drug supply reduction. These researches are supporting policymakers and law enforcement agencies in Brazil to strengthen the response to drug trafficking based on reliable evidence.https://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/05/cde-realiza-workshops-do-projeto-piloto-para-monitorar-precos-de-drogas-ilicitas-no-brasil-no-estado-de-pernambuco.htmlhttps://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/12/estudo-sobre-mercado-de-drogas-ilcitas-no-brasi.htmlhttps://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/11/lancam-curso-sobre-trafico-de-drogas-e-crime-organizado-transnacional.htmlhttps://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/11/recebem-delegacao-de-mocambique-para-troca-de-experiencia-na-area-de-gestao-de-ativos-originados-do-trafico-de-droga.htmlhttps://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/03/unodc-lanca-projeto-piloto-para-monitorar-precos-de-drogas-ilicitas-no-brasil.htmlhttps://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/01/subsistema-de-alerta-rpido-sobre-drogas-no-brasil-lana-primeiro-informe.html

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Outcome: 4.1 Em 2027, o Brasil terá fortalecido, no marco do estado democrático de direito, sua governança, legislação, capacidades e articulação institucionais com ampliação da participação popular para elaborar e executar políticas públicas baseadas em evidências, em direitos humanos e igualdade de geração, gênero, raça e etnia, com vistas à prevenção e ao enfrentamento à corrupção, ao crime e às múltiplas formas de violência, e orientadas às especificidades do território e à transparência, com inovação, cooperação nacional e internacional, e ampla participação da sociedade.
Output: 4.1.5 Capacidades governamentais fortalecidas para garantir uma abordagem multidimensional para combater crimes transnacionais, em especial durante crises humanitárias, e mitigar seus impactos sobre grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade, compartilhando informações e aprimorando políticas orientadas por evidências, voltadas ao respeito aos direitos humanos e baseadas na igualdade de geração, gênero, raça e etnia.
Sub-Output: UNODC BRACF23 PRIS-COOP Prison administration organizations' and law enforcement agencies' capacities strengthened to deal with organized crime in prisons in Brazil and Paraguay and with organized crime and illicit trafficking in the Amazon Tri-Border between Brazil, Colombia, and Peru
Description:
#SSC Paraguay, Peru, Colombia.
Project: PRIS-COOP.
Actual start date: 01/06/2021 | End date: 01/02/2024.

This project focuses on addressing the work of Transnational Criminal Organizations (TCOs) in Brazil and bordering countries. To enable so, it divides itself into two main objectives: the first aim is to promote the use, in Brazil and Paraguay, of innovative practices to enhance prison management in line with international minimum standards, with a focus on the challenges posed by organized crime in prisons, promoting cooperation between both countries. The second aim is to promote cooperation between Brazil, Paraguay, Peru and Colombia in implementing prison management best practices. PRIS-COOP is implemented under UNODC's mandate of the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and the United Nations Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners (Nelson Mandela Rules).
Agencies: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
Contributing partners: The US Government Department of State's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Implementation partners: The US Government Department of State's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
SDG Targets: 16.4 By 2030, significantly reduce illicit financial and arms flows, strengthen the recovery and return of stolen assets and combat all forms of organized crime.,16.a Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.,17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
SDG Goals: 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
LNOB groups targeted: Persons deprived of their liberty, Other
2023 Narrative: Project PRIS-COOP project focuses on addressing challenges posed by Transnational Criminal Organizations (TCOs) in Brazil and bordering countries. It divides itself into two main objectives: the first aim is to enhance prison management in Brazil and Paraguay, with a focus on the challenges posed by organized crime in prisons and on promoting cooperation between both countries. The second aim is to promote cooperation between Brazil, Peru and Colombia in combatting transnational organized crime in the Amazon region.One of the project’s main focuses is capacity-building: in Brazil, 344 prison agents received training, with an average improvement of 60,1% in their knowledge, based on pre- and post-training testing. It also promoted South-South cooperation between Brazil and Paraguay, resulting in 235 Paraguayan officers participating in training sessions conducted by Brazilian experts. In Paraguay, one of the activities was a Training of Trainers (ToT) in Prison Matters; by December 2023, these instructors had trained an additional 373 prison officers.PRIS-COOP organized several capacity-building and policy-focused activities. In Brazil, the project promoted seven (07) training sessions in partnership with the National Secretariat of Penal Policies (SENAPPEN). The project focused on strengthening state-level capacities in prison intelligence, training prison unit directors at the state and federal levels on dynamic security and enhancing the capacities of instructors of the National School for Criminal Services of SENAPPEN. In Paraguay, UNODC facilitated the organization of three (03) training sessions in partnership with Brazilian government agencies at the federal and state levels. The first course, in April, was on prison procedures and routines for the students at the Higher Technical Penitentiary Institute (ITSP) of Paraguay; then, in October, PRIS-COOP held a Training of Trainers on the theme. The third activity was aimed at prison unit Directors, to bolster leadership skills.  Additionally, PRIS-COOP supported four (04) international workshops to promote prison cooperation and police cooperation to address transnational organized crime within and outside prison settings. In parallel, UNODC worked to support Brazil and Paraguay in the theme of the classification of prisoners. In Paraguay, PRIS-COOP supported the development of general guidelines and an action plan for the development of a national classification system.In Brazil, UNODC was appointed as an official member of the National Technical Working Group to elaborate a National Standard on the Classification of Prisoners of the National Secretariat of Penitentiary Policies. The group will propose parameters for the implementation and operationalization of classification by the Brazilian states. UNODC was also invited to support the training of personnel on the SENAPPEN-supported pilot project on the classification of prisoners in Rio Grande do Norte, a Brazilian state which suffered a series of attacks against public buildings, businesses, public and private vehicles by prison-based organized groups in early 2023.
2024 Narrative: Under UNODC’s mandate to safeguard and implement The United Nations Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners, also known as the Nelson Mandela Rules, and in line with the United Nations System Common Position on Incarceration, over 4,100 prisoners underwent classification interviews in three Brazilian states with UNODC support. In Amapá, the entire prison population (3,317 people) was interviewed by nurses, psychologists, and social workers to identify individual needs (https://tinyurl.com/34kmkcz7). Classification is highlighted in both abovementioned documents as imperative in promoting the resocialization of prisoners, guaranteeing prisoners’ rights – especially to access basic services, work, and education – and improving security for prisoners and prison staff alike. After the initial interviews, each state must advance in 2025 in drafting Individualized Sentence Plans that will contain each prisoner’s personal plan in view of access to education, work, health needs, and more. In 2024, in order to promote best practices in humane prison management, UNODC promoted the Workshop ‘Individualizing Sentences: Implementation of the Classification of Prisoners’ and the First International Seminar on Prison Intelligence (https://tinyurl.com/3xu93rmz); overall, 236 people participated in both events in total. Additionally, the office translated the UN System Common Position on Incarceration. In 2024, UNODC trained 778 penal police officers, prison officers, and other law enforcement agents from Brazil, Paraguay, Peru, and Colombia on prison management – especially prisoner classification, prison intelligence, and operational protocols. 276 Brazilian penal police and other law enforcement officers were trained on prison intelligence topics(https://tinyurl.com/mpn2mtuc, https://tinyurl.com/488883sn).In Paraguay, 260 prison staff were trained in prison procedures and basic intelligence. Finally, six prison officers from Colombia and Peru participated in a training on prison intelligence held in the north of Brazil.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Outcome: ED2. Al 2025, la población, en especial la que está en condiciones de mayor vulnerabilidad, ejerce plenamente sus derechos a la salud, educación, cultura, vivienda, alimentación, protección social y de cuidados, y accede a servicios universales y a un sistema integral de cuidados de calidad.
Output: Pr2.3.
